<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Getting_Ready_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Getting_Ready">Getting Ready</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:53403-1-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53403" href="#/Image:53403-1-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled 53403 1 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e6/53403-1-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-1-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_4d10c5d964" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_4d10c5d964')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled 53403 1 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e6/53403-1-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-1-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Download and install a compiler.</b> C code needs to be compiled by a program that interprets the code into signals that the machine can understand. Compilers are usually free, and different compilers are available for different operating systems.

<ul>
<li>For Windows, try Microsoft Visual Studio Express or MinGW.</li>
<li>For Mac, XCode is one of the best C compilers.</li>
<li>For Linux, <a href="/Compile-a-C-Program-Using-the-GNU-Compiler-(GCC)" title="Compile a C Program Using the GNU Compiler (GCC)">gcc</a> is one of the most popular options.</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:53403-2-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53403" href="#/Image:53403-2-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled 53403 2 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4e/53403-2-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-2-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_fe1a75b979" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_fe1a75b979')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled 53403 2 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4e/53403-2-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-2-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Understand the basics.</b> C is one of the older programming languages, and can be very powerful. It was designed for Unix operating systems, but has been ported and expanded for nearly all operating systems. The modern version of C is <a href="/Learn-C%2B%2B-Programming" title="Learn C++ Programming">C++</a>.

<ul>
<li>C is essentially comprised of functions, and in these functions you can use variables, conditional statements, loops to store and manipulate data.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:53403-3-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53403" href="#/Image:53403-3-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled 53403 3 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f4/53403-3-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-3-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_186343a494" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_186343a494')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled 53403 3 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f4/53403-3-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-3-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Examine some basic code.</b> Take a look at the (very) basic program below to get a good idea about how some of the various aspects of the language work together, and to get an idea of how programs function.

<div class="codebox" style="display:inline-block; background-color: #f6f5f4; border-style: dashed; border-width: 1px; border-color: #000000; padding-top: .5em; padding-bottom: .5em; padding-left: .5em; overflow: auto;margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:0.5em;border-radius: 4px;-moz-border-radius: 4px;-webkit-border-radius: 4px;border: 1px solid #000; width:100%;">
<div class="mw-geshi mw-code mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr">
<div class="c source-c">
<pre class="de1">
<span class="co2">#include <stdio.h></span>
 
<span class="kw4">int</span> main<span class="br0">(</span><span class="br0">)</span> 
<span class="br0">{</span>
    <span class="kw3">printf</span><span class="br0">(</span><span class="st0">"Hello, World!<span class="es1">\n</span>"</span><span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
    <span class="kw3">getchar</span><span class="br0">(</span><span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
    <span class="kw1">return</span> <span class="nu0">0</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
<span class="br0">}</span>
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup><ul>
<li>The <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">#include</kbd> command occurs before the program starts, and loads libraries that contain the functions you need. In this example, <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">stdio.h</kbd> lets us use the <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">printf()</kbd> and <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">getchar()</kbd> functions.</li>
<li>The <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">int main()</kbd> command tells the compiler that the program is running the function called "main" and that it will return an integer when it is finished. All C programs run a "main" function.</li>
<li>The <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">{</kbd>} indicate that everything inside them is part of the function. In this case, they denote that everything inside is a part of the "main" function.</li>
<li>The <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">printf()</kbd> function displays the contents of the parentheses on the user's screen. The quotes ensure that the string inside is printed literally. The <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">\n</kbd> sequence tells the compiler to move the cursor to the next line.</li>
<li>The <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">;</kbd> denotes the end of a line. Most lines of C code need to end with a semicolon.</li>
<li>The <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">getchar()</kbd> command tells the compiler to wait for a keystroke input before moving on. This is useful because many compilers will run the program and immediately close the window. This keeps the program from finishing until a key is pressed.</li>
<li>The <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">return 0</kbd> command indicates the end of the function. Note how the "main" function is an <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">int</kbd> function. This means that it will need an integer to be returned once the program is finished. A "0" indicates that the program has performed correctly; any other number will mean that the program ran into an error.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:53403-4-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53403" href="#/Image:53403-4-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled 53403 4 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c9/53403-4-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-4-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_e1db98a855" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e1db98a855')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled 53403 4 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c9/53403-4-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-4-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Try compiling the program.</b> Enter the code into your code editor and save it as a "*.c" file. Compile it in your compiler, typically by clicking the Build or Run button.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:53403-5-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53403" href="#/Image:53403-5-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled 53403 5 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bb/53403-5-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-5-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_d4c5dc4325" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_d4c5dc4325')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled 53403 5 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bb/53403-5-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-5-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Always comment on your code.</b> Comments are part of the code that is not compiled, but allows you to explain what is happening. This is useful for reminding yourself what your code is for, and for helping other developers who might be looking at your code.

<ul>
<li>To comment in C place <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">/*</kbd> at the start of the comment and <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">*/</kbd> at the end.</li>
<li>Comment on all but the most basic parts of your code.</li>
<li>Comments can be used to quickly remove parts of your code without deleting them. Simply enclose the code you want to exclude with comment tags and then compile. If you want to add the code back, remove the tags.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,4805470868" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">
<div id="methodad"></div>
<script>googletag.cmd.push(function() { googletag.display('methodad'); });</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Using_Variables_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Using_Variables">Using Variables</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:53403-6-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53403" href="#/Image:53403-6-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled 53403 6 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/39/53403-6-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-6-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_cccb02ec84" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_cccb02ec84')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled 53403 6 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/39/53403-6-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-6-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Understand the function of variables.</b> Variables allow you to store data, either from computations in the program or from user input. Variables need to be defined before you can use them, and there are several types to choose from.

<ul>
<li>Some of the more common variable types include <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">int</kbd>, <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">char</kbd>, and <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">float</kbd>. Each one stores a different type of data.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:53403-7-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53403" href="#/Image:53403-7-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled 53403 7 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6b/53403-7-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-7-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_816f7464f5" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_816f7464f5')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled 53403 7 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6b/53403-7-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-7-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Learn how variables are declared.</b> Variables need to be established, or "declared", before they can be used by the program. You declare a variable by entering the data type followed by the variable's name. For example, the following are all valid variable declarations:

<div class="codebox" style="display:inline-block; background-color: #f6f5f4; border-style: dashed; border-width: 1px; border-color: #000000; padding-top: .5em; padding-bottom: .5em; padding-left: .5em; overflow: auto;margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:0.5em;border-radius: 4px;-moz-border-radius: 4px;-webkit-border-radius: 4px;border: 1px solid #000; width:100%;">
<div class="mw-geshi mw-code mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr">
<div class="c source-c">
<pre class="de1">
<span class="kw4">float</span> x<span class="sy0">;</span>
<span class="kw4">char</span> name<span class="sy0">;</span>
<span class="kw4">int</span> a<span class="sy0">,</span> b<span class="sy0">,</span> c<span class="sy0">,</span> d<span class="sy0">;</span>
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<ul>
<li>Note that you can declare multiple variables on the same line, as long as they are the same type. Simply separate the variable names with commas.</li>
<li>Like many lines in C, each variable declaration line needs to end with a semicolon.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:53403-8-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53403" href="#/Image:53403-8-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled 53403 8 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b4/53403-8-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-8-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_a55b76504e" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a55b76504e')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled 53403 8 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b4/53403-8-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-8-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Know where to declare variables.</b> Variables must be declared at the beginning of each code block (The parts of your code that are enclosed in {} brackets). If you try to declare a variable later in the block, the program will not function correctly.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:53403-9-1.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53403" href="#/Image:53403-9-1.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled 53403 9 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5c/53403-9-1.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-9-1.jpg" height="546" id="img_5bca4ec94b" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5bca4ec94b')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled 53403 9 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5c/53403-9-1.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-9-1.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use variables to store user input.</b> Now that you know the basics of how variables work, you can write a simple program that will store the user's input. You will be using another function in the program, called <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">scanf</kbd>. This function searches the input that is provided for specific values.

<div class="codebox" style="display:inline-block; background-color: #f6f5f4; border-style: dashed; border-width: 1px; border-color: #000000; padding-top: .5em; padding-bottom: .5em; padding-left: .5em; overflow: auto;margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:0.5em;border-radius: 4px;-moz-border-radius: 4px;-webkit-border-radius: 4px;border: 1px solid #000; width:100%;">
<div class="mw-geshi mw-code mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr">
<div class="c source-c">
<pre class="de1">
<span class="co2">#include <stdio.h></span>
 
<span class="kw4">int</span> main<span class="br0">(</span><span class="br0">)</span>
<span class="br0">{</span>
  <span class="kw4">int</span> x<span class="sy0">;</span>
 
  <span class="kw3">printf</span><span class="br0">(</span> <span class="st0">"Enter a number: "</span> <span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
  <span class="kw3">scanf</span><span class="br0">(</span> <span class="st0">"%d"</span><span class="sy0">,</span> <span class="sy0">&</span>x <span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
  <span class="kw3">printf</span><span class="br0">(</span> <span class="st0">"You entered %d"</span><span class="sy0">,</span> x <span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
  <span class="kw3">getchar</span><span class="br0">(</span><span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
  <span class="kw1">return</span> <span class="nu0">0</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
<span class="br0">}</span>
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<ul>
<li>The <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">"%d"</kbd> string tells <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">scanf</kbd> to look for integers in the user input.</li>
<li>The <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">&</kbd> before the variable <var>x</var> tells <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">scanf</kbd> where to find the variable in order to change it, and stores the integer in the variable.</li>
<li>The final <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">printf</kbd> command reads back the input integer to the user.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:53403-10-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53403" href="#/Image:53403-10-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled 53403 10 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/15/53403-10-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-10-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_0349a84749" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_0349a84749')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled 53403 10 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/15/53403-10-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-10-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Manipulate your variables.</b> You can use mathematical expressions to manipulate the data that you have stored in your variables. The most important distinction to remember for mathematical expressions is that a single <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">=</kbd> sets the value of the variable, while <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">==</kbd> compares the values on either side to see if they are equal.

<div class="codebox" style="display:inline-block; background-color: #f6f5f4; border-style: dashed; border-width: 1px; border-color: #000000; padding-top: .5em; padding-bottom: .5em; padding-left: .5em; overflow: auto;margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:0.5em;border-radius: 4px;-moz-border-radius: 4px;-webkit-border-radius: 4px;border: 1px solid #000; width:100%;">
<div class="mw-geshi mw-code mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr">
<div class="c source-c">
<pre class="de1">
x <span class="sy0">=</span> <span class="nu0">3</span> <span class="sy0">*</span> <span class="nu0">4</span><span class="sy0">;</span> <span class="coMULTI">/* sets "x" to 3 * 4, or 12 */</span>
x <span class="sy0">=</span> x <span class="sy0">+</span> <span class="nu0">3</span><span class="sy0">;</span> <span class="coMULTI">/* adds 3 to the original value of "x", and sets the new value as the variable */</span>
x <span class="sy0">==</span> <span class="nu0">15</span><span class="sy0">;</span> <span class="coMULTI">/* checks to see if "x" equals 15 */</span>
x <span class="sy0"><</span> <span class="nu0">10</span><span class="sy0">;</span> <span class="coMULTI">/* checks if the value of "x" is less than 10 */</span>
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,4805470868" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Using_Conditional_Statements_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Using_Conditional_Statements">Using Conditional Statements</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:53403-11-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53403" href="#/Image:53403-11-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled 53403 11 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/98/53403-11-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-11-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_f09f12224d" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f09f12224d')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled 53403 11 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/98/53403-11-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-11-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Understand the basics of conditional statements.</b> Conditional statements are what drive most programs. They are statements that are determined to be either TRUE or FALSE, and then acted upon based on the result. The most basic of the statements is the <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">if</kbd> statement.

<ul>
<li>TRUE and FALSE work differently in C than what you might be used to. TRUE statements always end up equaling a nonzero number. When you perform comparisons, if the result is TRUE then a "1" is returned. If the result is FALSE, then a "0" is returned. Understanding this will help you see how IF statements are processed.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:53403-12-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53403" href="#/Image:53403-12-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled 53403 12 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f2/53403-12-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-12-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_d5cccae155" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_d5cccae155')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled 53403 12 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f2/53403-12-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-12-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Learn the basic conditional operators.</b> Conditional statements revolve around the use of mathematical operators that compare values. The following list contains the most commonly used conditional operators.

<div class="codebox" style="display:inline-block; background-color: #f6f5f4; border-style: dashed; border-width: 1px; border-color: #000000; padding-top: .5em; padding-bottom: .5em; padding-left: .5em; overflow: auto;margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:0.5em;border-radius: 4px;-moz-border-radius: 4px;-webkit-border-radius: 4px;border: 1px solid #000; width:100%;">
<div class="mw-geshi mw-code mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr">
<div class="c source-c">
<pre class="de1">
<span class="sy0">></span>   <span class="coMULTI">/* greater than */</span>
<span class="sy0"><</span>   <span class="coMULTI">/* less than */</span>
<span class="sy0">>=</span>  <span class="coMULTI">/* greater than or equal to */</span>
<span class="sy0"><=</span>  <span class="coMULTI">/* less than or equal to */</span>
<span class="sy0">==</span>  <span class="coMULTI">/* equal to */</span>
<span class="sy0">!=</span>  <span class="coMULTI">/* not equal to */</span>
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p><br/></p>
<div class="codebox" style="display:inline-block; background-color: #f6f5f4; border-style: dashed; border-width: 1px; border-color: #000000; padding-top: .5em; padding-bottom: .5em; padding-left: .5em; overflow: auto;margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:0.5em;border-radius: 4px;-moz-border-radius: 4px;-webkit-border-radius: 4px;border: 1px solid #000; width:100%;">
<div class="mw-geshi mw-code mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr">
<div class="c source-c">
<pre class="de1">
<span class="nu0">10</span> <span class="sy0">></span> <span class="nu0">5</span> TRUE
<span class="nu0">6</span> <span class="sy0"><</span> <span class="nu0">15</span> TRUE
<span class="nu0">8</span> <span class="sy0">>=</span> <span class="nu0">8</span> TRUE
<span class="nu0">4</span> <span class="sy0"><=</span> <span class="nu0">8</span> TRUE
<span class="nu0">3</span> <span class="sy0">==</span> <span class="nu0">3</span> TRUE
<span class="nu0">4</span> <span class="sy0">!=</span> <span class="nu0">5</span> TRUE
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:53403-13-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53403" href="#/Image:53403-13-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled 53403 13 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a4/53403-13-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-13-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_5cc747078c" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5cc747078c')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled 53403 13 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a4/53403-13-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-13-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Write a basic IF statement.</b> You can use IF statements to determine what the program should do next after the statement is evaluated. You can combine it with other conditional statements later to create powerful multiple options, but for now write a simple one to get used to them.

<div class="codebox" style="display:inline-block; background-color: #f6f5f4; border-style: dashed; border-width: 1px; border-color: #000000; padding-top: .5em; padding-bottom: .5em; padding-left: .5em; overflow: auto;margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:0.5em;border-radius: 4px;-moz-border-radius: 4px;-webkit-border-radius: 4px;border: 1px solid #000; width:100%;">
<div class="mw-geshi mw-code mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr">
<div class="c source-c">
<pre class="de1">
<span class="co2">#include <stdio.h></span>
 
<span class="kw4">int</span> main<span class="br0">(</span><span class="br0">)</span>
<span class="br0">{</span>
  <span class="kw1">if</span> <span class="br0">(</span> <span class="nu0">3</span> <span class="sy0"><</span> <span class="nu0">5</span> <span class="br0">)</span>
    <span class="kw3">printf</span><span class="br0">(</span> <span class="st0">"3 is less than 5"</span><span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
    <span class="kw3">getchar</span><span class="br0">(</span><span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
<span class="br0">}</span>
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:53403-14-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53403" href="#/Image:53403-14-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled 53403 14 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3e/53403-14-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-14-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_ef9e79ad31" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ef9e79ad31')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled 53403 14 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3e/53403-14-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-14-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use ELSE/ELSE IF statements to expand your conditions.</b> You can build upon IF statements by using ELSE and ELSE IF statements to handle different results. ELSE statements run if the IF statement is FALSE. ELSE IF statements allow you to include multiple IF statements into one code block to handle various cases. See the example program below to see how they interact.

<div class="codebox" style="display:inline-block; background-color: #f6f5f4; border-style: dashed; border-width: 1px; border-color: #000000; padding-top: .5em; padding-bottom: .5em; padding-left: .5em; overflow: auto;margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:0.5em;border-radius: 4px;-moz-border-radius: 4px;-webkit-border-radius: 4px;border: 1px solid #000; width:100%;">
<div class="mw-geshi mw-code mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr">
<div class="c source-c">
<pre class="de1">
<span class="co2">#include <stdio.h></span>
 
<span class="kw4">int</span> main<span class="br0">(</span><span class="br0">)</span>
<span class="br0">{</span>
  <span class="kw4">int</span> age<span class="sy0">;</span>
 
  <span class="kw3">printf</span><span class="br0">(</span> <span class="st0">"Please enter your current age: "</span> <span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
  <span class="kw3">scanf</span><span class="br0">(</span> <span class="st0">"%d"</span><span class="sy0">,</span> <span class="sy0">&</span>age <span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
  <span class="kw1">if</span> <span class="br0">(</span> age <span class="sy0"><=</span> <span class="nu0">12</span> <span class="br0">)</span> <span class="br0">{</span>
    <span class="kw3">printf</span><span class="br0">(</span> <span class="st0">"You're just a kid!<span class="es1">\n</span>"</span> <span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
  <span class="br0">}</span>
  <span class="kw1">else</span> <span class="kw1">if</span> <span class="br0">(</span> age <span class="sy0"><</span> <span class="nu0">20</span> <span class="br0">)</span> <span class="br0">{</span>
    <span class="kw3">printf</span><span class="br0">(</span> <span class="st0">"Being a teenager is pretty great!<span class="es1">\n</span>"</span> <span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
  <span class="br0">}</span>
  <span class="kw1">else</span> <span class="kw1">if</span> <span class="br0">(</span> age <span class="sy0"><</span> <span class="nu0">40</span> <span class="br0">)</span> <span class="br0">{</span>
    <span class="kw3">printf</span><span class="br0">(</span> <span class="st0">"You're still young at heart!<span class="es1">\n</span>"</span> <span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
  <span class="br0">}</span>
  <span class="kw1">else</span> <span class="br0">{</span>
    <span class="kw3">printf</span><span class="br0">(</span> <span class="st0">"With age comes wisdom.<span class="es1">\n</span>"</span> <span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
  <span class="br0">}</span>
  <span class="kw1">return</span> <span class="nu0">0</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
<span class="br0">}</span>
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup><ul>
<li>The program takes the input from the user and takes it through the IF statements. If the number satisfies the first statement, then the first <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">printf</kbd> statement is returned. If it does not satisfy the first statement, it is taken through each ELSE IF statement until it finds one that works. If it doesn't match any of them, it goes through the ELSE statement at the end.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Learning_Loops_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>4</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Learning_Loops">Learning Loops</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_4">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:53403-15-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53403" href="#/Image:53403-15-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled 53403 15 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f0/53403-15-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-15-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_a3d06e79cf" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a3d06e79cf')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled 53403 15 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f0/53403-15-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-15-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Understand how loops work.</b> Loops are one of the most important aspects of programming, as they allow you to repeat blocks of code until specific conditions are met. This can make repeating actions very easy to implement, and keeps you from having to write new conditional statements each time you want something to happen.

<ul>
<li>There are three main types of loops: FOR, WHILE, and DO...WHILE.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:53403-16-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53403" href="#/Image:53403-16-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled 53403 16 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/13/53403-16-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-16-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_7f3029dd56" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_7f3029dd56')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled 53403 16 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/13/53403-16-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-16-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use a FOR loop.</b> This is the most common and useful loop type. It will continue running the function until the conditions set in the FOR loop are met. FOR loops require three conditions: initializing the variable, the condition to be met, and the way the variable is updated. If you don't need all of these conditions, you will still need to leave a blank space with a semicolon, otherwise the loop will run forever.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
<div class="codebox" style="display:inline-block; background-color: #f6f5f4; border-style: dashed; border-width: 1px; border-color: #000000; padding-top: .5em; padding-bottom: .5em; padding-left: .5em; overflow: auto;margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:0.5em;border-radius: 4px;-moz-border-radius: 4px;-webkit-border-radius: 4px;border: 1px solid #000; width:100%;">
<div class="mw-geshi mw-code mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr">
<div class="c source-c">
<pre class="de1">
<span class="co2">#include <stdio.h></span>
 
<span class="kw4">int</span> main<span class="br0">(</span><span class="br0">)</span>
<span class="br0">{</span>
  <span class="kw4">int</span> y<span class="sy0">;</span>
 
  <span class="kw1">for</span> <span class="br0">(</span> y <span class="sy0">=</span> <span class="nu0">0</span><span class="sy0">;</span> y <span class="sy0"><</span> <span class="nu0">15</span><span class="sy0">;</span> y<span class="sy0">++;</span><span class="br0">)</span><span class="br0">{</span>
    <span class="kw3">printf</span><span class="br0">(</span> <span class="st0">"%d<span class="es1">\n</span>"</span><span class="sy0">,</span> y <span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
  <span class="br0">}</span>
  <span class="kw3">getchar</span><span class="br0">(</span><span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
<span class="br0">}</span>
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<ul>
<li>In the above program, <var>y</var> is set to 0, and the loop continues as long as the value of <var>y</var> is less than 15. Each time the value of <var>y</var> is printed, 1 is added to the value of <var>y</var> and the loop is repeated. Once <var>y</var> = 15, the loop will break.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:53403-17-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53403" href="#/Image:53403-17-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled 53403 17 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c0/53403-17-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-17-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_ea6c1a2f19" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ea6c1a2f19')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled 53403 17 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c0/53403-17-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-17-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use a WHILE loop.</b> WHILE loops are more simple than FOR loops. They only have one condition, and the loop acts as long as that condition is true. You do not need to initialize or update the variable, though you can do that in the main body of the loop.

<div class="codebox" style="display:inline-block; background-color: #f6f5f4; border-style: dashed; border-width: 1px; border-color: #000000; padding-top: .5em; padding-bottom: .5em; padding-left: .5em; overflow: auto;margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:0.5em;border-radius: 4px;-moz-border-radius: 4px;-webkit-border-radius: 4px;border: 1px solid #000; width:100%;">
<div class="mw-geshi mw-code mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr">
<div class="c source-c">
<pre class="de1">
<span class="co2">#include <stdio.h></span>
 
<span class="kw4">int</span> main<span class="br0">(</span><span class="br0">)</span>
<span class="br0">{</span>
  <span class="kw4">int</span> y<span class="sy0">;</span>
 
  <span class="kw1">while</span> <span class="br0">(</span> y <span class="sy0"><=</span> <span class="nu0">15</span> <span class="br0">)</span><span class="br0">{</span>
    <span class="kw3">printf</span><span class="br0">(</span> <span class="st0">"%d<span class="es1">\n</span>"</span><span class="sy0">,</span> y <span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
    y<span class="sy0">++;</span>
  <span class="br0">}</span>
  <span class="kw3">getchar</span><span class="br0">(</span><span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
<span class="br0">}</span>
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<ul>
<li>The <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">y++</kbd> command adds 1 to the <var>y</var> variable each time the loop is executed. Once <var>y</var> hits 16 (remember, this loop goes as long as <var>y</var> is less than <i>or equal to</i> 15), the loop breaks.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:53403-18-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53403" href="#/Image:53403-18-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled 53403 18 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3d/53403-18-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-18-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_c6c55f2068" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c6c55f2068')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled 53403 18 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3d/53403-18-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-18-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use a <b>DO.</b>..WHILE loop.</b> This loop is very useful for loops that you want to ensure run at least once. In FOR and WHILE loops, the condition is checked at the beginning of the loop, meaning it could not pass and fail immediately. DO...WHILE loops check conditions at the end of the loop, ensuring that the loop executes at least once.

<div class="codebox" style="display:inline-block; background-color: #f6f5f4; border-style: dashed; border-width: 1px; border-color: #000000; padding-top: .5em; padding-bottom: .5em; padding-left: .5em; overflow: auto;margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:0.5em;border-radius: 4px;-moz-border-radius: 4px;-webkit-border-radius: 4px;border: 1px solid #000; width:100%;">
<div class="mw-geshi mw-code mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr">
<div class="c source-c">
<pre class="de1">
<span class="co2">#include <stdio.h></span>
 
<span class="kw4">int</span> main<span class="br0">(</span><span class="br0">)</span>
<span class="br0">{</span>
  <span class="kw4">int</span> y<span class="sy0">;</span>
 
  y <span class="sy0">=</span> <span class="nu0">5</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
  <span class="kw1">do</span> <span class="br0">{</span>
    <span class="kw3">printf</span><span class="br0">(</span><span class="st0">"This loop is running!<span class="es1">\n</span>"</span><span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
  <span class="br0">}</span> <span class="kw1">while</span> <span class="br0">(</span> y <span class="sy0">!=</span> <span class="nu0">5</span> <span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
  <span class="kw3">getchar</span><span class="br0">(</span><span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
<span class="br0">}</span>
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<ul>
<li>This loop will display the message even though the condition is FALSE. The variable <var>y</var> is set to 5 and the WHILE loop is set to run when <var>y</var> does not equal 5, so the loop terminates. The message was already printed since the condition is not checked until the end.</li>
<li>The WHILE loop in a DO...WHILE set must be ended with a semicolon. This is the only time a loop is ended with a semicolon.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Using_Functions_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>5</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Using_Functions">Using Functions</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_5">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:53403-19-1.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53403" href="#/Image:53403-19-1.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled 53403 19 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/86/53403-19-1.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-19-1.jpg" height="546" id="img_d9632eacde" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_d9632eacde')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled 53403 19 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/86/53403-19-1.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-19-1.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_5_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Understand the basics of functions.</b> Functions are self-contained blocks of code that can be called upon by other parts of the program. They make it very easy to repeat code, and they help make the program simpler to read and change. Functions can include all of the previously-covered techniques learned in this article, and even other functions.

<ul>
<li>The <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">main()</kbd> line at the beginning of all of the above examples is a function, as is <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">getchar()</kbd>
</li>
<li>Functions are essential to efficient and easy-to-read code. Make good use of functions to streamline your program.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:53403-20-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53403" href="#/Image:53403-20-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled 53403 20 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/73/53403-20-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-20-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_cdef4d9d1a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_cdef4d9d1a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled 53403 20 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/73/53403-20-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-20-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_5_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Start with an outline.</b> Functions are best created when you outline what you want it to accomplish before you begin the actual coding. The basic syntax for functions is "return_type name ( argument1, argument2, etc.);". For example, to create a function that adds two numbers:

<div class="codebox" style="display:inline-block; background-color: #f6f5f4; border-style: dashed; border-width: 1px; border-color: #000000; padding-top: .5em; padding-bottom: .5em; padding-left: .5em; overflow: auto;margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:0.5em;border-radius: 4px;-moz-border-radius: 4px;-webkit-border-radius: 4px;border: 1px solid #000; width:100%;">
<div class="mw-geshi mw-code mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr">
<div class="c source-c">
<pre class="de1">
<span class="kw4">int</span> add <span class="br0">(</span> <span class="kw4">int</span> x<span class="sy0">,</span> <span class="kw4">int</span> y <span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<ul>
<li>This will create a function that adds two integers (<var>x</var> and <var>y</var>) and then returns the sum as an integer.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:53403-21-1.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53403" href="#/Image:53403-21-1.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled 53403 21 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3e/53403-21-1.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-21-1.jpg" height="546" id="img_c0cbb4b8b7" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c0cbb4b8b7')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled 53403 21 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3e/53403-21-1.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-21-1.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_5_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Add the function to a program.</b> You can use the outline to create a program that takes two integers that the user enters and then adds them together. The program will define how the "add" function works and use it to manipulate the input numbers.

<div class="codebox" style="display:inline-block; background-color: #f6f5f4; border-style: dashed; border-width: 1px; border-color: #000000; padding-top: .5em; padding-bottom: .5em; padding-left: .5em; overflow: auto;margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:0.5em;border-radius: 4px;-moz-border-radius: 4px;-webkit-border-radius: 4px;border: 1px solid #000; width:100%;">
<div class="mw-geshi mw-code mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr">
<div class="c source-c">
<pre class="de1">
<span class="co2">#include <stdio.h></span>
 
<span class="kw4">int</span> add <span class="br0">(</span> <span class="kw4">int</span> x<span class="sy0">,</span> <span class="kw4">int</span> y <span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
 
<span class="kw4">int</span> main<span class="br0">(</span><span class="br0">)</span>
<span class="br0">{</span>
  <span class="kw4">int</span> x<span class="sy0">;</span>
  <span class="kw4">int</span> y<span class="sy0">;</span>
 
  <span class="kw3">printf</span><span class="br0">(</span> <span class="st0">"Enter two numbers to add together: "</span> <span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
  <span class="kw3">scanf</span><span class="br0">(</span> <span class="st0">"%d"</span><span class="sy0">,</span> <span class="sy0">&</span>x <span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
  <span class="kw3">scanf</span><span class="br0">(</span> <span class="st0">"%d"</span><span class="sy0">,</span> <span class="sy0">&</span>y <span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
  <span class="kw3">printf</span><span class="br0">(</span> <span class="st0">"The sum of your numbers is %d<span class="es1">\n</span>"</span> <span class="sy0">,</span> add<span class="br0">(</span> x<span class="sy0">,</span> y <span class="br0">)</span> <span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
  <span class="kw3">getchar</span><span class="br0">(</span><span class="br0">)</span><span class="sy0">;</span>
<span class="br0">}</span>
 
<span class="kw4">int</span> add <span class="br0">(</span> <span class="kw4">int</span> x <span class="sy0">,</span> <span class="kw4">int</span> y <span class="br0">)</span>
<span class="br0">{</span>
  <span class="kw1">return</span> x <span class="sy0">+</span> y<span class="sy0">;</span>
<span class="br0">}</span>
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<ul>
<li>Note that the outline is still located at the top of the program. This tells the compiler what to expect when the function is called and what it will return. This is only necessary if you want to define the function later in the program. You could define <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">add()</kbd> before the <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">main()</kbd> function and the result would be the same without the outline.</li>
<li>The actual functionality of the function is defined at the bottom of the program. The <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">main()</kbd> function collects the integers from the user and then sends them to the <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">add()</kbd> function to be processed. The <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">add()</kbd> function then returns the results to <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">main()</kbd>
</li>
<li>Now the <kbd style="background:#EEEEEE; letter-spacing:0.1em; padding-left:0.5em; padding-right:0.4em;">add()</kbd> has been defined, it can be called anywhere in the program.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Continuing_to_Learn_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>6</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Continuing_to_Learn">Continuing to Learn</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_6">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:53403-22-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53403" href="#/Image:53403-22-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled 53403 22 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/03/53403-22-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-22-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_58f41a2ac2" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_58f41a2ac2')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled 53403 22 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/03/53403-22-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-22-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_6_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Find a few C programming books.</b> This article covers the basics, but it only scratches the surface of C programming and all the associated knowledge. A good reference book will help you solve problems and save you from a lot of headaches down the road.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:53403-23-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53403" href="#/Image:53403-23-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled 53403 23 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c5/53403-23-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-23-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_f5c0667def" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f5c0667def')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled 53403 23 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c5/53403-23-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-23-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_6_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Join some communities.</b> There are lots of communities, both online and in the real world, dedicated to programming and all of the languages that entails. Find some like-minded C programmers to swap code and ideas with, and you will soon find yourself learning a lot.

<ul>
<li>Attend some hack-a-thons if possible. These are events where teams and individuals have time limits to come up with programs and solutions, and often foster a lot of creativity. You can meet a lot of good programmers this way, and hack-a-thons happen regularly across the globe.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:53403-24-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53403" href="#/Image:53403-24-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled 53403 24 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4a/53403-24-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-24-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_1803844503" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_1803844503')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled 53403 24 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4a/53403-24-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-24-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_6_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Take some classes.</b> You don't have to go back to school for a Computer Science degree, but taking a few classes can do wonders for your learning. Nothing beats hands-on help from people who are well-versed in the language. You can often find classes at local community centers and junior colleges, and some universities will allow you to audit their computer science programs without having to enroll.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:53403-25-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53403" href="#/Image:53403-25-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled 53403 25 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e9/53403-25-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-25-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_0a70a97650" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_0a70a97650')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled 53403 25 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e9/53403-25-2.jpg/aid53403-v4-728px-53403-25-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_6_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Consider learning C++.</b> Once you have a grasp of C, it wouldn't hurt to start taking a look at C++. This is the more modern version of C, and allows for a lot more flexibility. C++ is designed with object handling in mind, and knowing C++ can enable you to create powerful programs for virtually any operating system.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Questions_and_Answers_sub"></a>
<div class="qa section sticky qa_show_unanswered_questions" data-aid="53403" data-few_contribs="1" data-search_enabled="0">
<h2>
<div class="altblock"></div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="qa_headline">Community Q&A</span>
</h2>
<div class="section_text" id="qa">
<div id="qa_answered_questions_container">
<div id="qa_aq_search_container">
<div class="qa_section_heading" id="qa_aq_search_heading">Search</div>
<input class="qa_aq_search" placeholder="Type your query here"/>
</div>
<a id="qa_add_curated_question">Add New Question</a>
<ul class="qa_questions qa_aqs" id="qa_article_questions">
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="47968" data-caid="48841" data-cqid="47985" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="292163" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="6" data-votes_up="64">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What can I do if I don't understand any of this?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Learn a simpler language such as Python to understand the basics of programming before you start trying to learn C. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>6</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>64</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="104410" data-caid="105283" data-cqid="104427" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="565610" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="5" data-votes_up="43">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I understand the logic of programming, but I am having trouble with the syntax.  How do I resolve this?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">The only way is to keep practicing by writing lots of example programs of your own.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>5</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>43</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="142081" data-caid="142954" data-cqid="142098" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="683987" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="6" data-votes_up="40">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Is there an easy method to learn coding?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">C isn't a very beginner friendly language to learn. If I were you, I would start out by learning Python, which is a versatile, easy to use language. One of the best sites to learn it on is codecademy.com which is free, with a premium option that provides interactive lessons.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>6</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>40</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="234108" data-caid="234981" data-cqid="234125" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="989426" data-submitter_id="1328382" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="2" data-votes_up="17">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How do I create a program that receives a value, computes the square root of that value using a procedure function within the math.h library, and displays the square root as the output?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_ta_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle" style="background-image:url(https://www.wikihow.com/images/avatarOut/a/ac/1328382.jpg?20180124004903)"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"><span class="qa_user_link" data-href="/User:KommaH">KommaH</span></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Top Answerer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Use scanf() to have the user type in a value to your program. Store that value in a variable. Use the sqrt() function on that variable and use printf() to display the value.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>2</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>17</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="234106" data-caid="234979" data-cqid="234123" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1507424" data-submitter_id="1328382" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="3" data-votes_up="17">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I have been trying to learn C for a long time now, but I always blank out on what pointers or arrays do. What do I do?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_ta_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle" style="background-image:url(https://www.wikihow.com/images/avatarOut/a/ac/1328382.jpg?20180124004903)"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"><span class="qa_user_link" data-href="/User:KommaH">KommaH</span></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Top Answerer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Pointers and arrays (especially pointers) are by far the most headache-inducing features of C. Try not to focus on memorizing specific details about these features. Instead, focus on memorizing general information, such as when to use pointers/arrays, what they do, etc. Find good documentation that describes specific information such as operators, bookmark it, and then pull it out when you need to program using those features.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>3</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>17</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
</ul>
</div>

			{{/verifierId}}

			{{^verifierId}}

			{{/verifierId}}

				<div class="qa_answerer_info">
				{{#verifierId}}
					<div class="qa_user_name">
						<a href="{{#formatName}}{{verifierData.name}}{{/formatName}}" target="_blank">{{verifierData.name}}</a>
					</div>
					<div class="qa_user_title">{{{verifierData.blurb}}}</div>
				{{/verifierId}}

				{{^verifierId}}
					<div class="qa_user_name">{{{submitterDisplayName}}}</div>
				{{/verifierId}}

					<div class="qa_user_label">{{qa_answerer_label}}</div>

				</div>
			</div>

		{{#qa_desktop}}

				{{/qa_anon}}
			</div>
		{{/qa_desktop}}
		{{^qa_desktop}}
		<ul>
			<li class="qa_answer">{{{curatedQuestion.curatedAnswer.text}}}</li>
		</ul>
		{{> thumbs_up_down}}
		{{/qa_desktop}}
		</div>
	</div>
</li>

<div class="section tips sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tips">Tips</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="tips">
<ul>
<li>Always add comments to your programs. Not only does this help others who might take a look at its source code, but also it helps you remember what you're writing and why. You may know what you're doing the moment that you're writing your code, but after two or three months, you won't remember much.</li>
<li>Always remember to end a statement such as printf(), scanf(), getch(), etc with a semi-colon (;) but never insert them after a control statements like 'if', 'while' or 'for' loops.</li>
<li>When encountering a syntax error when compiling, if you're stumped, search Google (or another search engine) with the error you received. Chances are someone has already experienced the same problem and posted a solution.</li>
<li>Your source code needs to have a *.c extension, so that your compiler can understand that it's a C source file.</li>
<li>Always remember that practice makes perfect. The more you practice writing a program, the better you get at it. So start with simple, short programs until you get your footing, and then once you're confident you can move on to the more complex.</li>
<li>Try to learn logic building. It helps to tackle different problems while writing a code.</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
